summary: the Zika virus (ZIKV) is a flavivirus that was discovered in 1947 near Entebbe, Uganda. it is a flavivirus that was discovered in 1947 near Entebbe, Uganda. it is a flavivirus that was associated with a mild disease characterized by fever, rash, arthritis, and conjunctivitis. ZIKV has a positive sense ssRNA genome that encodes for one large polyprotein including three structural (C, M, and E) proteins and seven non-structural (NS1, NS2A, NS2B, NS3, NS4A, NS4B, and NS5) proteins. most, if not all, viruses encode proteins that interfere with the activation host innate immune responses. ZIKV NS2B-NS3 protein complex promotes the degradation of Jak1. NS1, NS2B3, NS4B, and NS5 proteins inhibit expression of IFIT2 gene. NS1, NS2B, NS4A, and NS5 proteins also inhibit IFN-induced. ZIKV NS5 interacts with IKK, an important downstream kinase of the RIG-I pathway. this interaction leads to impaired ability of IKK to phosphorylate and activate IRF3 leading to reduced activation of IFN promoters. plasmids for the wild type (wt) RIG-I, wtIRF3, FLAG-tagged MAVS, FLAG-tagged MAVS, FLAG-tagged TBK-1, FLAG-tagged IKK, and FLAG-tagged HCV NS3/4A have been described previously. multiple cloning site with segment from pGEX-2T(+) bacterial expression vector. inserted segment encodes glutathione S-transferase gene and contains a thrombin recognition site and the multiple cloning site with a BamHI recognition site. antibodies Rabbit anti-IRF3 (FL-425; Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Dallas, TX, USA), rabbit anti-phospho-IRF3 (Ser396) (4D4 guinea pig anti-ZIKV-NS5 was prepared against NS5 based on FB-GWUH-2016 sequence. IFN-1 is important in protecting epithelial barriers from virus infection. unlike other flaviviruses, ZIKV has the means to inhibit or delay the activation of innate immune responses. ZIKV NS5 inhibited RIG-I-induced activation of both IRF3- and NF-B transcription factors that coordinately regulate IFN-1 promoter activation. NS5 also inhibited IFN-1 promoter activation by all components of the RIG-I pathway upstream or at the level of IRF3. Xia et al. [21] reported that NS5 inhibited the activation of the promoter.
